title: ‘Liberty’s Chain’ Review: Making Abolition a Family Affair
sub_head: Tracing the journey from slave ownership to full-throated abolitionism in the generations of a prominent New York family.
body:
In the landscape of American political history John Jay and his descendants may perhaps seem like lesser outcroppings, overshadowed by the cliff-like profiles of more prominent men. But their role in the formation of the early republic—and in America’s evolving self-definition over time—was a crucial one. In David Gellman, a historian at DePauw University, they have at last found a superb though not uncritical chronicler. “Liberty’s Chain: Slavery, Abolition, and the Jay Family of New York” brings into sharp focus three generations of one of the nation’s most remarkable families.
Mr. Gellman is primarily concerned with the Jays’ tangled relation to slavery and antislavery. In this way, his clear-eyed narrative will undoubtedly take its place alongside other studies with a similar theme—for instance, Henry Wiencek’s “An Imperfect God: George Washington, His Slaves, and the Creation of America” (2003) and Annette Gordon-Reed’s “The Hemingses of Monticello” (2008). In the Jays’ case, the time-frame stretches beyond the founding era—and far beyond the legal demise of slavery in the Jays’ home state of New York.
